For all the people confused let me explain why it was offensive by both Pepsi & Kendall. 

A huge company like Pepsi making a commercial at the same time multiple black people were murdered by the cops and the marches were at a high was extremely insensitive, almost profiting off the deaths of individuals. To top it off they choose Kendall Jenner of all people to lead the "march"? Not a protester, never attended a Black Lives Matter march, never really spoke out on the subject, probably never experienced institutional racism/racial inequality.

If she had any morals or values she should have declined this offer instead of thinking about the money. She can cry all she wants but there is no way she didn't see the controversy in this, it's insulting to even think about offering her this role.

Why was there a problem with the Pepsi ad? It's just an ad, and yes it's cringey and over-dramatic, but I think people way overreacted on this one.

+Katy Moore
Well, I'm sorry I didn't know about that.
But I have heard MANY stories of protestors blocking traffic without license or permission, especially around where I live.

No, they were not blocking traffic. During a protest, you don't block traffic. You give in notice to the city that you're doing a peaceful assembly and get streets blocked off. This gives warning to residences. If you pay attention and live in a city where protests normally happen (i.e. a capital) you'll know detours to use, what days major protests are happening and when you'll need to leave. Protestors don't just randomly all decide "hey, today I'm going to bring a bunch of signs and block people!", they are rarely, if ever spontaneous.

Also, no, he wasn't fricking running people over because they were in traffic. He was running them over because he was a terrorist with little to no value on human life who decided to kill the people he didn't agree with. He was a monster, that I don't believe can be justified.

It was a dumb commercial, but the idea of it was to give the same visual as when a young woman offered a flower as a symbol of peace to a military police officer at the October 21, 1967 March on the Pentagon; only with it being a pepsi instead of a flower.

Not exactly something that needs to be hated to the degree people do.  The fact that so many of the younger generation are getting so pissed at this shows they haven't even opened a history text of their own country to be able to see the parallels.

The handing of the can was inspired by that specific moment, but the commercial in general was clearly trying to cash in on recent events. You've got to be pretty naive to think a multi-billion dollar corporation like Pepsi gives a damn about delivering a positive message, their only concern is their bottom line.

To be honest, Pepsi and other brand-name product providers have done commercials like this where there product was the answer, and nobody cared because it was just a commercial. Of course they want to say that their product solves the problem. 

The only reason they care now is because they're brainwashed. Look at what Pepsi did. They took these crowds of idiots and morons out there mindlessly following whatever some liberal leader tells them to do, thinking whatever some liberal leader instructs them to think, and Pepsi made them all look like reasonable peaceful demonstrators fighting for a noble cause. And then they're sooo stupid, all they could do was turn and bite Pepsi and skewer them. And why, because they're mindlessly programmed to think Pepsi is some evil rich empire out to make a cheap buck on their protest using superficial pretty face.

But the truth is, Pepsi along with many others always do commercials like this covering a variety of topics from global warming to education. Is this really anything different? Not really. Of course Pepsi's not the answer. It's not the answer to saving our rain forests and giving people a better education either, but they use those topics too to promote their product like it's the answer. And nobody cares because it's just a commercial.

Oh, and don't think I'm for Pepsi. I won't be shopping for their products anymore. They want to pander to fools, then that's fine, I'll buy from other companies. The fact that they were skewered was only because they chose to side with idiots and morons before they did their homework to know what they're allowed to present and what they aren't. 

But don't let that deter you from making videos like this. This video was pretty funny. You can support the moronic idiots that march our streets all you want. Just remember, Democrats command the loyalty of the vast majority of our news, so a lot of what you see is filtered in an effort to benefit Democrats and the left wing in some way. I'm sure you have that problem in Britain and Sweden as well. It's hard to learn how to discern bias from truth, and it's never an exact science. It's more of a subjective intuition based in likelihood and that which you know to be true. That's why personal biases make it even harder to discern. And I am very biased against the Democrats and the left wing as it is today in America. So, you know, that's where I'm coming from in the interests of truth.

+Wictoria,
 So because their job is to sell Pepsi, they cant use symbolism to "touch" people and try to cause an emotional impact to influence people? They have to make black and white- simple little ads because, YOU SAY that's their job? Have you ever seen madmen? It's very on par with marketing strategy in the real world. Do you really think that they should take your advice when nearly every study out there shows that this is exactly the strategy that works the BEST? Tying your product to emotions like love, peace, happiness, togetherness etc.

Message and goal are two different things in marketing and analysis. The *message* is obviously peace and togetherness, generosity in times of adversity. And because we, as people, tend to value those kinds of things, THAT is supposed to touch your heart, and then accomplish their *goal* of making you think of pepsi as a good product associated with the good vibes you felt during the commercial. It's 2017, an ad released on youtube counts as 'aired'. Pepsi's intentions unfortunately are irrelevant. Trump could have the best intentions by deporting all those people, bypassing congress to launch those missile air strikes in syria, and 'building' that wall on the mexican border but if you're one of the millions getting deported, bombed, or protesting against real injustice, and someone makes light of your struggle? Awful. And from a company as big as pepsi. It's the same as Pepsi releasing an official statement saying, "Feminism? Police brutality? lol chill out, have a nice cold pepsi (and give us your money)". Unfortunately the world isn't so forgiving for sizeable people, companies, organisations, etc. to be so insensitive with how they communicate their product. Might as well have made an ad of a medic team tending to the wounded chemical bombing victims in Syria with a Pepsi and everyone being ok and the civil war being resolved and rainbows and unicorns start singing. It's not about realistic ads, it's about the message that is conveyed through even the most unrealistic ads. Look up satire and parody for some obvious examples.

Danny Choi So what if they made light of controversial issues it's just an advertisement. This ad isn't negatively effecting anybody in real life. Why get your panties in a wad over an advertisement that wasn't even aired? Besides I don't think Pepsi was actually trying to do anything bad by making this ad.  They were just trying to show solidarity with different movements and people took it the wrong way. Can you really not tell the difference between an ad and real life?

At first I was wondering what was so offensive about the ad. Then Felix proceeded to not only explain the (now apparent) flaws of the ad, but he basically tore it to shreds. I laughed so hard a few times!

But yeah, now I think I see what's wrong. The ad seems to suggest that all the injustice and hate in the world can be eradicated by something as simple as giving a cop a Pepsi. Plus, I can see what would make it inauthentic: the unrealistic portrayal of how protests occur, the way the ad seems to be trying too hard to pander towards the audience instead of trying to sympathize with us, the way it probably looked like Kendall was just trying to get publicity and a paycheck...
The only good thing about this ad is that it made me realize that somewhere out there, slick and beautiful plain Pepsi cans exist.

In a time where bullshit rules -  advertisers should be jumping on being genuine, being down to earth, being humble before the complicated quagmires of society's problems.

I bet the comments sections here could come up with a hundred ideas good enough for an advert for gross sugar fizz!

How about an app where you manage the cola company? Free to play but it's an ad, with the real logos and  figures? Like Adventure Capitalist but not just a clicker.

Or a video ad that shows the history of their older adverts, their printing press ads from nineteen dickity-five but the ads come to live in an animation with that sort of engraved art?

Or remake the logo through a worldwide competition, the winner gets money to donate to their charity of choice, and some money for their own work? Or they get to adopt a village in a third world country for the rest of their lives.. kinda like a cash-every-month lottery, but the company pays out to that village? It would cost far less than a jenner advert. 

Or an advert showing all the money they donate to charity, but in ratio--- moneydonated:moneyerned. 

Or an app that lets you get in game currency for some popular games per can? 

Or.. have an ideas competition instead of hiring people so out of touch with reality, they thought this garbage commercial was good? 

I bet you all can come up with better. Maybe I am being spoiled on youtube and other internet entertainment with genuine people, people who aren't being paid by some rich old crazies to make formula based rubbish all day long, that I think we should now demand it and boycott the real BS factories.

Pewdiepie I love you so much, but I don't think you understood. It wasn't that the Pepsi "saved everything" it is about reaching out to the cops as well. It is trying to symbolize that there are some cops that are not violent and that are out doing their jobs. (I don't want to anger anyone. I acknowledge that not all cops are peaceful and that there is hate and tear gas and violence overall, but I think that this Ad was trying to reach for the peaceful side of protesting. This isn't the only one, there were also things like the "hug campaign " that went out to hug anyone protesting. I know there are violent protests and that the world isn't all a shade or rosy pink, but this Ad was trying to "show" that we can do that. I KNOW it takes forever but we could. ) Also just a disclaimer I do not like Kendall Jenner -.- I am not trying to defend her, I'm just saying that there is a deeper meaning in this Ad.

I just think that we have to remember this commercial never directly said it was about BLM. Pepsi said that it was purely meant to be about unity and peace, and they may have missed the mark, but in my own personal opinion, it's being blown out of proportion. People are mad at an ad that was not meant to say that a soda can fix all our problems. They meant to send a good message, and it's not something that we should just assume was supposed to be a simple topic. I think that Phil DeFranco made a really good point about this in one of his videos. I get why people are upset, but this is all based on the assumption that Pepsi wanted to just say, "Oh, this can be fixed with a drink."
It's a really deep conversation, and I think these days it's important to remember a lot of us just want to be together. There are people who want to make everything a fight, but its just dumb to get pissed off at an ad when you should be focused on more important things going on around us.

Guys. This Pepsi commercial was based on that picture of that woman who confronted and was arrested by those cops in the Baton Rouge protests which were started in part by the shootings of  Alton Sterling and Philando Castile by police. As we all know this caused a lot of upheaval in the African American community as well as in the BLM movement because those shootings clearly could have been avoided. I don’t know how much anyone knows about the whole police brutality movement and racism but it’s actually a big thing in the African American community and people were outraged about that for months. This Pepsi ad was aired not too long after this happened. So obviously just the fact that this Pepsi commercial makes light of the situation and shows people cheering instead of rioting is enough to be outraged. I’m not mad at Kendall; I literally think she just is uneducated about certain topics and made a stupid decision. People SHOULD be mad at Pepsi. You cannot make light of someone’s pain and suffering; only the person going through the pain and suffering is justified in making light of their own situation. Furthermore if the actual woman—Ieshia Evans—or for God’s sake ANY African American woman was used in the Pepsi ad, it thus because ones own nation making light of their own situation. Any other way around and that’s just mockery. The same applies to a grieving or terminally ill person. 
Also, imagine a pepsi commercial, but instead of police brutality, they show something on a larger scale like the holocaust, right? Imagine a scene where a line of Jews are kneeling in front of ditches with nazis behind them ready to execute them; but then one of the Jews turns around and gives them a Pepsi and they all start cheering as if the Holocaust never happened. How do you think a Jew, or even a Holocaust survivor would feel? I think we all know that’d be very inappropriate due to the fact that the Holocaust was so devastating. Well news flash, the deaths of  Alton Sterling and Philando Castile, along with all of the other countless African American men and women who lost their lives to injustice or for unnecessary reasons is also devastating. People have a right and a reason to get upset about this. Just because YOU don’t see why it’s so offensive doesn’t mean there’s “nothing wrong with this.” There IS something wrong with this. The problem is that only those who are or have been oppressed know the anger and frustration and pain that comes with your oppression being turned into a joke, or worse, a marketing scheme to make money to rich white people who have never been oppressed a day in their lives. We must learn our history in order to be able to determine whether or not someone is justified in their anger. And we, as a nation, have to stop labeling people as “too sensitive” for something that was downright wrong. Pepsi should never have even conceived the idea for this commercial. Period. And Kendall needs to be more aware of social politics and the issues we face as a nation day in and day out before accepting roles or jobs that could cause her backlash in the first place.

I'm shocked at how many people don't see what the problem is.  And I feel horrible that they would drag Kendall into this.  Its not her fault.  If someone has never been affected by racism or sexism or poverty or homophobia then they don't see the problem of white privilege and how this is perpetuated in this ad.  What people are fighting for in protests, in activism, in politics are civil right and human rights that protect us from violence and discrimination.  So when a big ugly corporation makes a "lighthearted" depiction of that struggle, there is nothing real about it and it starts a privileged actress of a reality show... uh.... obviously it is a mockery of the struggles, and the pain, the downright physical violence that minorities of all sorts have lived through.  Everyone is pointing to the photo of Iesha Evans.  Do the police look armed and scary and as sh*t in that photo?  Yes... She is a symbol and the reality of bravery when she faced the police in their riot gear.  In the commercial the police are these twinky dinky cute actors with ball caps.  

If you don't understand the controversy please read more and get educated!  We need an intelligent and informed youth.  Pepsi shouldn't have made this commercial, they should have made a HUGE donation to the ACLU.  And to the education of America.  Oh and in case you missed it when Kendall's character (I don't even want to say her because she is being used in this commercial for their agenda) is getting all excited and she whips her wig off she storms out the door and throws her wig at the black photo shoot assistant.  You may think people are reading into it too much, but I'm not the only one.  Media is loaded with symbols, and this is another one.  Hollywood movies and commercials are packed with racist, sexist, homophobic, anti Islamic,  anti overweight etc etc symbols.  Why is almost every single leading actress white, skinny, and blond in the movies?  Obviously we live in a racist society where the white the character is going to steal the show.  Just like Kendall's character is doing here.  She is being used to steal the energy of the movement of social justice and sell you a fu$&king Pepsi Cola.  Get it?  Its so inappropriate.  No one can dilute the power of the real movement.  Power to the People!!!! Yazzzzzzzzzz

It's also so embarrassingly fake, topical and shallow. They take the symbol of struggle for a lot of fed up people and extort it for their benefit by turning it into some weird, fake, idyllic after school special. That's not what a real protest looks, and they're often not pretty. They are using social issues and current events to shlock their dumbass product. And then, at the end, it's all good, everyone cheers, because some out-of-touch, uber rich, famous-for-being-famous, nobody celebrity gives a cop a damn Pepsi. Like, wtf? Again, it cheapens the real issues that are being protested today. It's so self serving and self righteous and disingenuous and fake. Stay out of social issues Pepsi, no one cares for your stupid take on it.

The common misconception that I keep on seeing in these comments is people referring to the content in the ad as a protest. What is displayed in the ad is not a protest, it was a march for peace. Two VERY different things! They were not protesting against anything at all, it was a huge group of people of all races, nationalities, gender, and sexual orientation. They were holding up peace signs saying join the conversation, that is hardly a protest. The pepsi can was symbolic of an olive branch or flower, they weren't saying here have a pepsi it will make things better, they were conveying the message of extending peace. I am seeing so many people make this into something bigger then what it actually is. Now if you want to see something truly offensive, racist, near sided, etc. then read some of these comments, they are the real problem. Not a company making a bold step saying that we need peace.

People dislike the ad because Pepsi has taken the hallmarks of organic social movement and resistance (which has nothing to do with profiteering) and used them for financial gain. You cannot compare hippies putting flowers into the gun barrels of policemen with Kendall Jenner handing a cop a soda. They are total opposites - the hippies confronted police because they were rejecting global violence, government policy and, crucially, capitalist agendas. Kendall's on-screen action is entirely centred on making a profit - something that the hippy movement stood against. It also trivialises the problems and hopelessness that drives people to protest in the first place by saying that everything can be fixed with a smile and a Pepsi. For many people, protesting is the only way they can make their voice heard and hope to effect any kind of positive change. Pepsi have taken that ugly reality and turned it into a stylish fashion show that does not reflect the unhappy reality of many people's lives. Essentially, this is not what a protest looks like. Protesting is not something that needs to or should be glamorized. A protest is not Coachella. At the end of the day, Pepsi did not dream up this article with the intent of empowering protesters across the world. They saw it as a way to drum up publicity and cash. These are just a few of the issues that people have with it. At the end of the day, it doesn't matter all that much, it's just a stupid, misjudged ad. Hope that helps :)

I like this ad.  It supports that the elite (Ms. Jenner) can be influenced by the masses (all colors).  Pepsi is the common thread.  Something that everyone can enjoy.  It could be coca cola, chocolate milk, coffee or orange juice, the product doesn't matter because it's symbology is "common bond," which in the end includes an officer.  Does anyone remember when the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam marched on the Pentagon in 1967?  A squad of armed guardsmen marched into the crowd of demonstrators and George Edgerly Harris III emerged from the crowd and placed carnations in the rifles.  Everyone knows that flowers can't stop atrocities, and neither can Pepsi, but still, there is symbolic significance in the gesture:  the use of nonviolent objects show that the demonstrations were not associated with anger or violence. The message is out of touch because the simple, pleasant scenario depicted in the ad doesn't exist, at least not in the public imagination. In this advertisement, there are two groups: law enforcement, and protesters. They are shown to be physically as well as psychologically divided, but by what catalyst? It almost seems like a celebration and not a march/protest because of the music in the background, the lack of provocative messages on signs, and the reasonably happy looking people (who are all young and good looking). The marketers wanted to depict the Pepsi brand as being a symbol of unity and peace. They constructed an oversimplified scenario to swoop in and save the day.

But the public was not fooled because the conflict depicted does not exist in reality. In the current era, we are not concerned with a tidy mass of peaceful protesters that form a neat line in front of a row of police officers and do not destroy the streetfronts around them. We are concerned with the mobs. They are not good-looking people with neat hair and soft expressions holding positive signs for their cause. Instead, they have backpacks and full facemasks, holding signs with provocative threats. They throw rocks and there is yelling and chaos all around. The police are on edge, and there are bright flashing lights and sirens from police cars. There's no music playing in the background, but instead there is a drive for self-preservation amid anarchic chaos directed towards the closest adversary. 

A peace offering cannot be made between these groups. One exists to quell the other, and one exists to create chaos and noise. They are fundamentally opposed groups, unlike in the fairytale land in the ad. It was controversial because people understand that it is false inherently. They don't need to type a short essay like I did to know why it is out of touch and exploitative of the current political landscape. 

It's like when the "great French princess" (commonly thought to be Marie Antoinette, but likely this is apocryphy) said "let them eat cake." There is no cake to be eaten by the masses. And even if there was, it's not the plight of the masses that they are hungry, but WHY they are hungry. Pepsi would be totally good if this was indeed an accurate representation of things. But it's not. It just shows their ignorance.

I think this is the problem with the ad: Many people were mad about it because it exemplified a protest, that looks nothing like most that happen around the world. Obviously Pepsi did not want to show an extremely violent protest to advertise their product, but the harsh reality is that most protests are met with brutal forces. Additionally, the fact that Kendall Jenner just walked in and “saved the day” aggravated people as well. She was just taking apart in a photo shoot when a nearby protest was happening, and the she became intrigued. It essentially shows that she had no intention of doing anything to fight for whatever issue was being protested for, until she saw that it was happening. It seems to be a parallel to some celebrities who are so caught up in their own world that they only join in on mainstream issues (not saying anything about Kendall Jenner here, they just used her as a symbol of fame.) I also think people are mad because this celebrity just walks up and stops the potential police forces by doing absolutely nothing, when these protestors presumably have been fighting for this issue for a long time. It made people feel like their issues aren’t going to be heard or responded to because they are not popular, rich, or famous.

Twitter is a horrible indicator of public opinion. Too many emotionally invested folks.
Pepsi has been running these kinds of ads forever, IMO it was because protest is viewed more negatively than before with the well known activist groups of today being extremely violent. Protest, on both the conservative and progressive sides, has been vindicated as mobs of angry, indoctrinated zombies. 
So Pepsi releases this ad expecting that a celebrity drop and some POCs would expend their revenue. Unfortunately, the Right is reminded of BLM while scoffing at the tokens. Meanwhile the Left draws parallels with some specific image that nobody knows about except them. Yeah, the ad is a co-op, but when was it not a co-op? 
What is odd is that the ad was definitely for the younger members of the political Left, and that ignoring any possibility of backlash from the Right was foolish. But despite all the heavy handed servicing to the Left, Pepsi failed to engage the target audience, or any audience.

I am doing a paper on this ad for my marketing /advertising class in college. This commercial was actually very well thought out and has a beautiful message. I don't even know where to begin. All of the signs say things like unity, peace, love, or have symbols such as hearts and peace signs...and there's even a sign that says "join the conversation" At 2:39 there are signs hanging from the buildings that have many languages on them  LEBE in German is LIVE , PAG IBIB in Filipino is LOVE. The song that is being played is by Bob Marley's grandson Skip Marley and som of the song is lions the lyrics are:
Some said 'never' but the never done come
Yeah, and took our trust
Hate's been winning, but the lovers ain't done
Yeah, not on my watch
Yeah, if ya took all my rights away
Yeah, if ya tellin' me how to pray
Yeah, if ya won't let us demonstrate
Yeah, wrong
Yeah, if ya thinking I don't belong
Yeah, if ya hiding behind a gun
Yeah, if ya hoping we're gonna run
Wrong
We are the lions, we are the chosen
We gonna shine out the dark
We are the movement, this generation
You better know who we are, who we are
Yeah, if…

you also notice in the commercial that there are many races and cultures and religions, but they are all joining together and walking and many are playing music or carrying instruments...music is the universal language. Also " join the conversation" is a twofold thing for one it means we should be talking about peace and harmony and love for all cultures, religions, and races and on the other hand there is a book called Join the Conversation: How to Engage Marketing-Weary Consumers with the Power of Community, Dialogue, and Partnership and they could be making reference to that also..Finally, this is NOT A PROTEST..this is a demonstration. There are never ever any demonstrations that don't have police officers there to just make sure things go ok. People are trying to compare Kendall giving the pepsi to an officer to a moment when a protestor got arrested Ieshia L. Evans, but they just don't compare. It's absurd! The demonstration in the pepsi commercial is not  racially charged, the only agenda is to support world peace and harmony, the cops are not in riot gear and their stance is relaxed and at ease. This has aboslutely nothing to do with police brutality or BLM. I just think that Pepsi was trying to convey a message, and because of all of the hate we can't even hear a message about peace and unity. Police brutality is very very wrong, but that's not what this commercial is about. It's sad because the removal of this commercial and backlash that it  recieved shows what a sad state our nation is in. More hate won't eradicate hate.

But just because in America we have electricity, “clean” water, and $0.79 generic Mac N Cheese, doesn’t mean there aren’t actual problems. Please tell me how someone making $10, 40 hours a week, 52 weeks, is supposed to support themselves and somehow better their future by going to tech school or college while living on $20,800 before any taxes. $20,800 is fuck all to get by on here in Green Bay WI, let alone big cities, and coastal cities. Unless you have a family that can somehow support you, you get completely stuck. I come from a poor family but luckily I wasn’t booted out of the house after high school and am able to live at home while going to college, so I don’t have housing costs, food costs (unless I eat out), and all the other little stuff. I can blatantly see how easily I could get stuck if I didn’t have a supportive family. And this is all best case scenario that you’re fresh out of high school, healthy, and have no other commitments. Now imagine having a kid, or having cancer, or being 40 where you’re likely completely on your own with little support from anyone unless you have a significant other. We’re not in the days of our parents and our grandparents and our great grandparents. There are very few jobs that you can go from high school to work and be able to support yourself and potentially a family. Back in my grandparents’ day you could come fresh out of high school, hell even just have an 8th grade education and as long as you were old enough you could get a job at some manufacturing plant and support a stay at home mom and kids all on your own. Now if you want to do that you either have to strike gold and get a union manufacturing job that only requires a high school diploma, or you have to get higher education, which isn’t free, and if you’re already broke with no credit, how are you supposed to pay for it. FAFSA helps but it certainly doesn’t cover the majority of the costs of any university, not even most tech schools. If back when we needed kids to stay in high school to get better skills for work which we then provided for free, why shouldn’t we do the same now with college as the economy changes.

Gonna stop here as I’m just ranting at this point. But people somehow miss the fact that it’s not 1960 anymore with a super strong manufacturing economy. We can’t just say “oh our grandparents ‘worked hard’ and were fine so why change anything, fuckin lazy millennials.”

Ay porfavor! Yo hablo perfecto ingles, español, un poco de Portuguese y un poco de frances. Soy de Mexico pero Naci en Los Estados Unidos y en mi juventud vivi en Mexico. Tambien tengo familia en Francia. So don't make THAT an excuse for your shitty grammar. But that's irrelevant and besides the point. Im not making excuses for the Jenner/Kardashian family. I'm just saying the facts, and even though it might seem like they can do whatever they want, they don't have a say in half of the shit they have to do (an example this ad) because they are under contracts that restrict what they can or can't say and do. The same thing happens when an actor acts in a movie. They cant speak about the movie UNTIL it comes out. They cant defend the movie if it gets bad reviews because if they say the wrong thing it could mean more bad than good. Even scandals are faked here in LA all the time. Its part of this business, its the way people in the spotlight make money, by staying relevant. DRAMA makes you relevant to the crowd, because people just LOVE drama and reality T.V. They didn't just become famous from their pretty faces. That is never enough, you need to be either a genius at marketing yourself, or hire a genius to market your image and manage how your life seems to the public eye. I WOULD judge Kendall if she did something fucked up. But all the reasons that people hate the Kardashians (because of scandals, drama) are stupid reasons because they literally don't affect me or the world in anyway. If you think they are fake bitches, its because they only show the public eye what they want the public eye to see. Its not that difficult to understand if you see it as what it is: A BUSINESS.

Ok I have to say something, I can’t stand this anymore. Now before anyone says I’m ignorant and stuff, I’d just want you to know that I’m all about equality and the end to all racism, sexism, homophobia and all that shit because this kind of hate in the world is absolutely not needed. But you know what kind of hate is unnecessary? The hate of all these people making fun and bashing celebs when all their doing is their job. You want to get upset with the ad? Then get upset with it. Kendall didn’t write the script. She didn’t direct it. All she did was act in it like everyone else in the ad. What aren’t people bashing the other people who were in the ad? Oh because they aren’t famous, and therefore nothing’s really to be said about them. But the ad too, it’s JUST an ad. If all of you take these ads so seriously then what has the world come to. At least they showed how racism was going on in the world. They just didn’t show the correct way to FIX it. But what do you expect? It’s an ad for a SOFT DRINK for goodness sake, y’all are just too sensitive to handle an ad that DIDNT find a good SOLUTION for fixing RACISM for a SOFT DRINK company and y’all are blaming it on Kendall?? Like?? I completely understand how she feels. She thought it was a big breakout. A chance to shine in her career but you guys pulled her down and laughed at her face. She didn’t know exactly what she was doing wrong and it maybe because she didn’t really think about it that much. Everyone just hates the Kardashians because they’re overhyped and stuff and yes, they are, but they’re just celebrities. Why do you hate people you’ve never met? People always preach about loving one another and ending all hate but y’all are hypocrites. Say they’re not talented, say they’re divas, idk about you but I have watched some of the episodes and they’re just obviously trying to entertain the viewers. They haven’t done anything shitty to the world like Trump did so why are y’all hating?? They have their careers, you have your life. And I bet all of you have something more productive to do than to hate on celebrities because I don’t hate people I’ve never met who haven’t seemed to have done anything wrong. Truth is, people are way too sensitive nowadays on things that aren’t even that big of a deal. Was the ad racist? No. It was just kind of stupid but still, it’s a soft drink ad you see. Idk but the internet likes to choose celebs to hate nowadays and everyone just hops onto that bandwagon without ever knowing why they’re hating. Maybe the Kardashians got it better than us, okay, but so what? They’re happy, if you’re upset then you’re obviously unhappy about your own life. They’re success does not affect yours or anyone’s life whatsoever. People say ‘there are people out there suffering and all the media does is focus on these divas’ but trust me when I say that these divas have done more to help those people than you ever have. They’ve donated millions, visited them, started campaigns. What have you done? Apart from hating on them all day. It doesn’t matter if another famous celebrity comes along. If you like them, it’s good. But if you don’t, it’s literally none of your business. They aren’t out here for your opinion. The world would be a better place without all the hate, and I mean ALL the hate. It’s unnecessary and revolting. Treat people with kindness. Show love, choose love. That’s al I have to say. I’m sorry if it’s too long but I believe in you and I believe everyone should be given a chance to shine in this world. Choose love.
